title: Sans Suggestions?
content:
Happy Friday!

I am designing a catalog for a lifestyle book publisher and want to use a more modern geometric sans. Along the lines of Gotham, with a range from condensed to extended. Any thoughts?

Appreciate any input! Happy Friday!

 [‹ Help with redesign fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20080423051003/http:/www.typophile.com/node/27287 "Go to previous forum topic") [A width between Regular and Condensed? ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080423051003/http:/www.typophile.com/node/27283 "Go to next forum topic")
author: NotoriousD

comments.content:
[proxima nova](http://web.archive.org/web/20080423051003/http:/www.ms-studio.com/FontSales/proximanova.html) could fit, but it hasnt got a extended, only normal, condensed and extra condensed… thats what [typographi.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20080423051003/http:/typographi.com/001045.php) wrote about it:  
<cite>Proxima Nova takes all that is good from faces such as Gotham, Neutraface, Futura, and Akzidenz Grotesk, and leaves what’s bad behind. It nestles neatly in a place between the geometric, grotesque, and gothic. Its generous x-height, thoughtfully balanced color, and expert typographic features (small caps, text figures, lining figures, etc.) position it as a prime candidate for extended textual setting. This is definitely Mr. Simonson’s tour de force. I wouldn’t be surprised to see Proxima Nova pop-up in the next major magazine redesign. — Kyle Hildebrant</cite>

and what about [avenir next](http://web.archive.org/web/20080423051003/http:/www.linotype.com/2090/avenirnext.html)?
I guess I don’t quite understand why geometric faces such as these really need an extended version. They’re already wide enough. Gotham is quite a wide face already.

i dont like extended faces anyway. i can see the use of a condensed cuts, but for an extended? i havent come across an extended cut that didnt look goofy and wrong to my eyes.

(of course, there are uses for them. i’d just rather design differently than use an extended cut)

(notoriousD, sorry for posting offtopic in your thread… i couldnt resist)

My thoughts for using an extended face is to provide a little variety to the template...mainly used on “headline” copy. The wider letterforms can provide a unique, progressive feel that will create a modern edge that the publisher wants.

I found [Relay](http://web.archive.org/web/20080423051003/http:/www.fontbureau.com/fonts/Relay) which is by far my favorite... a little pricey. But worth the cash!

Thanks so much for the suggestions!
